_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: cylinders, yokes, whips, flex lines, vacuum regulators, halogen valves
_prev_prog_2.Description: The facility has a preventative maintenance program in place.  Personnel are trained to operate the equipment and the training is regularly refreshed.  Receipt or changeout of chlorine cylinders takes place during the day time only.  Work in the area of the regulated process is performed by no fewer than two persons at any one time.  The design of the system included halogen valves for leak prevention, and leak detection devices that are wired to audio and visual alarms.  Inspections of the system are performed daily.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The City of Columbia Water Treatment Plant in McBaine, Missouri (Facility) is located approximately 10 miles south-southwest of Columbia, Missouri.  The Facility supplies potable water to Boone County.  The Facility stores and uses the following Clean Air Act Section 112 (CA-112) regulated substances in the following regulated processes:

Substance ? Chlorine
Process ? Wastewater treatment (chlorination)

The chlorine used at the Facility is stored in 1-ton cylinders and a maximum quantity of approximately 30,000 pounds is present at any one time.  There is one chlorine process at the Facility consisting of eight cylinders in use at all times.  There have been no chlorine releases or accidents at the Facility in the past five years.  There are public receptors immediately adjacent to the Facility.  

Due to the hazardous nature of chlorine, the City of Columbia Water Treatment Plant has coordinated with the Columbia Fire Department to respond to emergencies.  The Facility has generated the Risk Management Plan (RMP) to minimize the potential risk to plant personnel and surrounding communities.  A complete Prevention Program is included that is consistent with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration requirements for Process Safety Management.  An Emergency Response Plan has also been prepared with detailed instructions for handling a chlorine release at the Facility.  Water plant employees undergo continuous safety training and the process line is inspected daily.  In addition, the Facility has installed an automated discharge detection system (including halogen valves) that significantly reduces the risk of chlorine release.  The valves are automated and close all eight on-line cylinders immediately following detection of chlorine in the cylinder room, feed room or in the basement below the cylinder room.

As required for the RMP, the Facility has evaluated the chlorination process line to identify possible sources of chlorine releases.

In addition, the off-Site impact of both a worst case and an alternative release scenario has been evaluated using RMP*Comp.   Results of the off-Site impact analyses are presented in the RMP submittal.

In addition to existing prevention and response efforts, the City of Columbia Water Treatment Plant personnel are also making modifications to further insure safe ope4ration.  Emergency lighting has been upgraded, the chlorine detectors are being integrated into the SCADA system, and training and maintenance procedures are being continuously improved.
